Sec. 2-31. - Meetings. (a) The city council shall meet at city hall in the city council chambers in Richmond Hill, Georgia, at 7:30 p.m. on the first and third Tuesday of each month. (b) Special meetings of the city council will be called in the discretion of the mayor or at the request of at least three members of the council. Whether such special meeting is called at the discretion of the mayor or at the request of at least three members of the council, all the members of the council, unless absent from the city, shall have notice. (c) For any meeting that is to be held at a time or place other than at the time and place prescribed for regular meetings, the city council shall give due notice thereof as prescribed by O.C.G.A. § 50-14-1(d). State Law reference— Meetings to be open to public, O.C.G.A. § 50-14-1; exemptions from open meeting requirements, O.C.G.A. § 50-14-3; due notice requirements for other than regular meetings, O.C.G.A. § 50-14-1(d); requirement to prescribe the time, place and dates of regular meetings of governing authority, O.C.G.A. § 50-14-1(d). Sec. 2-32. - Preparation of agenda. (a) Unless this requirement is waived by affirmative vote of all members of the city council present at a meeting, all items to be presented to the city council for debate or action at their regular meetings shall first be placed upon an agenda pursuant to the procedure outlined below. Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit the authority of the presiding officer to recognize members of the audience from speaking on issues on the agenda, provided such person is first recognized by the chair. (b) The city clerk is authorized and directed to prepare an agenda for each regular and called meeting. Citizens, elected officials, department heads, and other interested persons who wish to have issues addressed at a city council meeting shall so inform the city clerk by using the following procedure: (1) All requests for items to be placed on the agenda shall be made upon the agenda issues requests form maintained in the city clerk's office. (2) Such requests must be submitted on the proper form by the close of business, one full business day prior to the city council meeting at issue. (c) The city clerk is authorized to screen requests to be placed on the agenda so as to reroute items that may be more appropriately addressed at the administration level or are more appropriately addressed to other deliberating bodies. The city clerk may also reject applications regarding old business already settled by the city council. The city clerk will not, however, have authority to defer requests by members of the city council to have an item placed on an agenda. Sec. 2-33. - Parliamentary rules. Except as provided in this article, Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised, shall generally be the official authority for rules governing the conduct of meetings of the city council. Secs. 2-34—2-65. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - AUTHORITIES, BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS[3] Footnotes: --- (3) --- State Law reference— Code of ethics for members of boards, commissions and authorities, O.C.G.A. § 45-10-3.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Secs. 2-66—2-85. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY[4]
Footnotes: --- (4) --- Editor's note— An ordinance of June 16, 1998, §§ 101—108, has been treated as superseding the provisions of former Div. 2, §§ 2-86—2-94 at the discretion of the editor. Former Div. 2 pertained to the development authority, and derived from an ordinance of June 20, 1995, §§ 2—10. State Law reference— Development Authorities Law, O.C.G.A. § 36-62-1 et seq.
Sec. 2-86. - Authority created. There is need for an authority as defined in an Act of the General Assembly of Georgia, approved 1963, (Ga. L. 1963, p. 531, § 1 and Ga. L. 1969, p. 137, § 1; O.C.G.A. sec. 36-62-1, et. sec., hereinafter referred to as the "development authorities law"), to function, exist and be operated in and for the geographical area of Bryan County, Georgia, as defined herein, and the City of Richmond Hill and there is hereby activated, created and organized such an authority, to be known as the Joint Bryan County/City of Richmond Hill Development Authority ("authority"), as provided in and by the development authorities law. (Ord. of 6-16-98, § 101) Sec. 2-87. - Powers of authority. The authority shall have all of the powers allowed or provided under the development authorities law, as now enacted or later amended including, but without limiting the generality of the foregoing, the power: (1) To bring and defend actions; (2) To adopt and amend a corporate seal; (3) To make and execute contracts and other instruments necessary to exercise the powers of the authority, and of which contracts may be made with the county or with any one or more municipal corporations in the county; (4) To receive and administer gifts, grants, and devises of any property and to administer trusts; (5) To acquire, by purchase, gift, or construction, any real or personal property desired to be acquired as part of any project (as defined in the development authorities law) or for the purpose of improving, extending, adding to, reconstructing, renovating, or remodeling any project or part thereof already acquired or for the purpose of demolition to make room for such project or any part thereof; (6) To sell, lease, exchange, transfer, assign, pledge, mortgage, dispose of, or grant options for any real or personal property or interest therein for any such purposes; (7) To dispose of any real property for fair market value, regardless of prior development of such property as a project, whenever the board of directors of the authority may deem such disposition to be in the best interests of the authority if the board of directors of the authority prior to such disposition shall determine that such real property no longer can be used advantageously as a project for the development of trade, commerce, industry, and employment opportunities; (8) To mortgage, convey, pledge, or assign any properties, revenues, income, tolls, charges, or fees owned or received by the authority; (9) To appoint officers and retain agents, engineers, attorneys, fiscal agents, accountants, and employees and to provide for their compensation and duties; (10) To extend credit or make loans to any person, firm, corporation, or other industrial entity for the planning, design, construction, acquisition, or carrying out of any project, which credit or loans shall be secured by loan agreements, mortgages, security agreements, contracts, and all other instruments, fees, or charges, upon such terms and conditions as the authority shall determine reasonable in connection with such loans, including provision for the establishment and maintenance of reserves and insurance funds; and, in the exercise of powers granted by the development authorities law in connection with a project for such person, firm, corporation, or other industrial entity, to require the inclusion in any contract, loan agreement, security agreement, or other instrument, of such provisions for guaranty, insurance, construction, use, operation, maintenance, and financing of a project as the authority may deem necessary or desirable; (11) To acquire, accept, or retain equitable interests, security interests, or other interest in any property, real or personal, by mortgage, assignment, security agreement, pledge, conveyance, contract, lien, loan agreement, or other consensual transfer, in order to secure the repayment of any moneys loaned or credit extended by the authority; (12) To construct, acquire, own, repair, remodel, maintain, extend, improve, and equip projects located on land owned or leased by the authority or land owned or leased by others and to pay all or part of the cost of any such project from the proceeds of revenue bonds of the authority or from any contribution or loans by persons, firms, or corporations or any other contribution, all of which the authority is authorized to receive, accept, and use; (13) To borrow money and issue its revenue bonds and bond anticipation notes from time to time and to use the proceeds thereof for the purpose of paying all or part of the cost of any project, including the cost of extending, adding to, or improving the project, or for the purpose of refunding any such bonds of the authority theretofore issued and to otherwise carry out the purposes of the development authorities law and to pay all other costs of the authority incident to or necessary and appropriate to such purposes, including the providing of funds to be paid into any fund or funds to secure such bonds and notes, provided that all such bonds and notes shall be issued in accordance with the procedures and subject to the limitations set forth in the development authorities law. (14) As security for repayment of authority obligations, to pledge, mortgage, convey, assign, hypothecate, or otherwise encumber any property, real or personal, of the authority and to execute any trust agreement, indenture, or security agreement containing any provisions not in conflict with law, which trust agreement, indenture, or security agreement may provide for foreclosure or forced sale of any property of the authority upon default, on such obligations, either in payment of principal or interest or in the performance of any term or condition, as are contained in such agreement or indenture. (15) If the authority authorizes an air transportation facility, to contract with any county or municipal corporation in the state; (16) To expend for the promotion of industry, agriculture, and trade within its geographical area, any funds of the authority determined by the authority to be in excess of those needed for the other corporate purposes of the authority; and (17) To do all things necessary or convenient to carry out the development authorities law, as amended. (Ord. of 6-16-98, § 102) Sec. 2-88. - Geographical area. The geographical area of the authority shall be all of that portion of the county, lying south of Fort Stewart Military Reservation, including such portion within the city limits of the city. (Ord. of 6-16-98, § 103) Sec. 2-89. - Board of directors. The authority shall consist of a seven-member board of directors. The directors shall be taxpayers residing in the geographical area of the authority described in section 2-88. The county board of commissioners ("commissioners") shall appoint four members of the board of directors and the Richmond Hill city council ("city council") shall appoint three members of the board of directors. One director appointed by the commissioners may be the chairman of the commissioners or a member of the commissioners and one director appointed by the city council may be the mayor of the city or a member of the city council, however no full time employee of either the county or the city may be appointed as a director. (Ord. of 6-16-98, § 104) Sec. 2-90. - Appointment of original members of the board of directors. To comply with the section of the development authorities law relating to lengths of terms of successors to original members of the board of directors (O.C.G.A. section 36-62-4(a)), the first two members of the board of directors shall be appointed by the county, the next two members shall be appointed by the city, the next two members shall be appointed by the county and the final member shall be appointed by the city. (Ord. of 6-16-98, § 105) Sec. 2-91. - Compensation of directors. Members of the board of directors shall receive no compensation for their services, but shall be reimbursed for their actual expenses incurred in the performance of their duties, provided such reimbursement is approved by vote of the board of directors. (Ord. of 6-16-98, § 106) Sec. 2-92. - Length of existence. The authority shall have perpetual existence. (Ord. of 6-16-98, § 107) Sec. 2-93. - Reports. As frequently as requested by either the commissioners or the city council, or at least every three (3) months if not so requested, the authority shall, by written report to the commissioners and city council, summarize its activities for the period of time from its last written report. (Ord. of 6-16-98, § 108) Secs. 2-94—2-125. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - PLANNING COMMISSION[5]
Footnotes: --- (5) --- Editor's note— The city's comprehensive land use plan, having been approved by the Coastal Georgia Regional Development Center and the state department of community affairs was adopted by resolution of October 5, 1993, as the City of Richmond Hill Comprehensive Land Use Plan pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 36-70-1 et seq. An official copy of the plan is on file in the office of the city clerk. Cross reference— Subdivisions, ch. 58; zoning, app. A. State Law reference— Redevelopment Powers Law, O.C.G.A. § 36-44-1 et seq.; coordinated and comprehensive planning by counties and municipalities, O.C.G.A. § 36-70-1 et seq.; regional development centers, O.C.G.A. § 50-8-30 et seq.; authority to adopt plans and exercise zoning powers, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ IV.
Sec. 2-126. - Creation. The Richmond Hill Planning Commission, referred to in this division as the "planning commission," is hereby created and established. (Ord. No. 12, § 6-1-1, 5-5-70) Sec. 2-127. - Membership. The planning commission shall consist of five members, who shall be residents and qualified electors of the city, appointed by the mayor and council. The terms of the members shall be four years. Any vacancy in membership shall be filled for the unexpired term by the mayor and council, who shall also have the authority to remove any member for cause, on written charges, after a public hearing. All members shall serve without compensation but may be reimbursed for actual expenses incurred in connection with their official duties. (Ord. No. 12, § 6-1-2, 5-5-70) Sec. 2-128. - Officers. The planning commission shall elect its chairman from among its members. The term of the chairman shall be one year with eligibility for re-election. The planning commission shall appoint a secretary who may be an officer or employee of the municipality. (Ord. No. 12, § 6-1-3(a), 5-5-70) Sec. 2-129. - Meetings; records. The planning commission shall make its own rules of procedure and determine its time of meeting. All meetings of the planning commission at which official action is taken shall be open to the public and all records of the planning commission shall be a public record. (Ord. No. 12, § 6-1-3(a), 5-5-70) Sec. 2-130. - Staff; outside services. The planning commission may appoint such employees and staff as it may deem necessary for its work and may contract with the state planning agency and city planners and other consultants for such services as it may require. (Ord. No. 12, § 6-1-3(b), 5-5-70) Sec. 2-131. - Expenditures. The expenditures of the planning commission, exclusive of gifts, shall be within the amounts appropriated for the purpose by the mayor and council. (Ord. No. 12, § 6-1-3(b), 5-5-70) Secs. 2-132—2-140. - Reserved. DIVISION 4. - ARCHITECTURAL REVIEW BOARD[6]
Footnotes: --- (6) --- Editor's note— An ordinance adopted May 21, 2013, enacted provisions designated as div. 4, §§ 2-201—2-207. Inasmuch as said sections already exist, the provisions have been redesignated as div. 4, §§ 2-141—2-147, at the discretion of the editor.
Sec. 2-141. - Creation. The Richmond Hill Architectural Review Board, referred to in this division as the "ARB," is hereby created and established. The architectural review board will advise and assist the planning and zoning commission, during the schematic and development stages of signs and projects submitted for approval, with the review of proposed signage, landscaping and architectural standards with the guidelines set forth in the zoning ordinance and the subdivision regulations. The ARB will provide comments and recommendations in an effort to preserve the specific character and historical significance of the City of Richmond Hill. (Ord. of 5-21-13) Sec. 2-142. - Duties. The Richmond Hill ARB shall consider the aesthetic qualities of a proposed sign, commercial building and/or landscaping plan, in relation to all pertinent city ordinances, including but not limited to the sign's, commercial building's and/or landscaping plan's appearance, size, location, structure, materials, color, and cohesiveness in relation to the sign, commercial building and/or landscaping plan's surroundings and shall prepare a recommendation for approval, approval with conditions, or denial of the application. The recommendation of the ARB will be transmitted to the zoning administrator for inclusion in the zoning administrator's report to the planning commission. (Ord. of 5-21-13) Sec. 2-143. - Organization. The ARB shall consist of five members appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the council. Members of the ARB will function as "quasi" public officials and as such will be required to subscribe to both the state public officials oath and the code of ethics of the City of Richmond Hill. The terms of the members shall be two years. Any vacancy in membership shall be filled for the unexpired term by the mayor with the advice and consent of the council, who shall also have the authority to remove any member for cause, on written charges, after a public hearing. All members shall serve without compensation but may be reimbursed for actual expenses incurred in connection with their official duties. (Ord. of 5-21-13) Sec. 2-144. - Officers. The ARB shall elect its chairman from among its members. The term of the chairman shall be one year with eligibility for re-election. The ARB shall appoint a secretary who may be an officer or employee of the municipality. (Ord. of 5-21-13) Sec. 2-145. - Meetings; records. The ARB shall make its own rules of procedure and determine its time of meeting. All meetings of the ARB at which official action is taken shall be open to the public and all records of the ARB shall be a public record. (Ord. of 5-21-13) Sec. 2-146. - Staff; outside services. The ARB may, with the consent of the mayor and council, appoint such employees and staff as it may deem necessary for its work. (Ord. of 5-21-13) Sec. 2-147. - Expenditures. The expenditures of the ARB, exclusive of gifts, shall be within the amounts appropriated for the purpose by the mayor and council. (Ord. of 5-21-13) Secs. 2-148—2-200. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - CODE OF ETHICS DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 2-201. - Definitions. City councilmember shall be any person who is an elected city official, including the mayor, of the city. Employee shall be any person who is a full-time or part-time employee of the city. Government or city shall be construed to mean the City of Richmond Hill, Georgia government. (Ord. of 1-4-00) Sec. 2-202. - Acceptance of gifts. City council members shall not solicit or accept directly or indirectly anything of value from any person, corporation, or group which: (1) Has, or is seeking to obtain contractual or other business or financial relationships with the city; (2) In exchange for the thing of value seeks to have a council member exercise a matter of discretion in his or her favor; (3) In exchange for the thing of value seeks to have interests which may be affected by the performance or nonperformance of the official duty of the council member; (4) This section shall not apply to campaign contributions which shall be reported in accordance with state laws. (Ord. of 1-4-00) Sec. 2-203. - Intent. It is the intent of this section that city council members avoid any action whether or not specifically prohibited by section 2-201 which might result in, or create the appearance of the following: (1) Using public office for private gain; (2) Impeding government efficiency or economy; or (3) Affecting adversely the confidence of the public in the integrity of the government. (Ord. of 1-4-00) Sec. 2-204. - Financial interests of members. City council members may not: (1) Have direct or indirect financial interests that conflict substantially with their responsibilities and duties as government servants; or (2) Engage in, directly or indirectly, financial transactions as a result of, or primarily relying upon, information obtained from their office. Aside from these restrictions, city council members are free to engage in lawful financial transactions to the same extent as private citizens. (Ord. of 1-4-00) Sec. 2-205. - Use of public property. A city council member shall not use government property of any kind for other than officially approved activities, nor shall he or she direct employees to use such property for these purposes. (Ord. of 1-4-00) Cross reference— Rental and use of city facilities; rules and regulations, ch. 2, art. V; special requirements for caterers, ch. 6, art. VI; drinking in public, § 50-8. Sec. 2-206. - Use of confidential information. A city council member shall not directly or indirectly, make use of, or permit others to make use of, for the purpose of furthering a private interest, official information not made available to the general public. (Ord. of 1-4-00) Sec. 2-207. - Coercion by council members. A city council member shall not use his position in any way to coerce, or give the appearance of coercing, another person to provide any financial benefit to him or persons within his immediate family, or those with whom a council member has business or financial ties. (Ord. of 1-4-00) Sec. 2-208. - Voting in matters of personal interest. A city council member shall not vote on an ordinance or amendment in a city council meeting that would directly affect his or her private business. (Ord. of 1-4-00) Sec. 2-209. - Unauthorized purchases. A city council member shall not order any goods and services for the city without prior official authorization for such an expenditure. (Ord. of 1-4-00) Sec. 2-210. - Meetings of the council. Meetings of the council shall be conducted in accordance with the O.C.G.A., title 50, ch. 14, as amended, and title 36, ch. 80, § 1, as amended, as it applies to municipalities. (Ord. of 1-4-00) Sec. 2-211. - City attorneys used for private business. A city council member shall not use the attorney or attorneys who are under retainer by the city, for personal or private business without paying just compensation. (Ord. of 1-4-00) Sec. 2-212. - Unauthorized use of public employees. A city council member shall not use his superior position to request or require an employee to: (1) Do clerical work on behalf of his family, business, social, church or fraternal interests; (2) Purchase goods and services to be used for personal, business, or political purposes; and (3) Work for him personally without offering just compensation. (Ord. of 1-4-00) Sec. 2-213. - Travel expenses. A city council member shall not draw per diem or expense monies from the city to attend a seminar, convention, or conference and then fail to attend the seminar, convention, or conference without refunding the pro-rata unused per diem or expense monies to the city. (Ord. of 1-4-00) Sec. 2-214. - Penalties. The code of ethics to be observed by city council members are set forth above and any violation thereof shall subject the offender to disciplinary action which may include censure and either public or private reprimand. Power to administer a greater punishment shall include power to administer the lesser. (Ord. of 1-4-00) Secs. 2-215—2-220. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATION
Sec. 2-221. - Ethics committee. The ethics committee shall consist of three persons, one appointed by the mayor, one appointed by the council, and the third appointed by the two above named subject to approval by a majority of the city council. The third member of the ethics committee shall be a member in good standing of the State Bar of Georgia. All members shall serve a two-year term. (Ord. of 1-4-00) Sec. 2-222. - Receipt of complaints. (a) All complaints against city council members shall be filed with the ethics committee in writing and signed by the complainant. (b) Upon receipt of a complaint in proper form, the ethics committee shall review it to determine whether the complaint is unjustified, frivolous, patently unfounded or fails to state facts sufficient to invoke the disciplinary jurisdiction of the city council. The ethics committee shall be empowered to collect evidence and information concerning any complaint and to add the findings and results of its investigations to the file containing such complaint. (c) Upon completion of its investigation of a complaint, the ethics committee shall be empowered to dismiss those complaints which are unjustified, frivolous, patently unfounded or which fail to state facts sufficient to invoke the disciplinary jurisdiction of the city council; provided, however, that a rejection of such complaint by the ethics committee shall not deprive the complaining party of any action he might otherwise have at law or in equity against the respondent government servant. (d) The ethics committee shall be empowered to conduct probable cause investigations, to take evidence and hold hearings where provided for in the rules. (e) The ethics committee shall be empowered to adopt forms for formal complaints, subpoenas, notices, applications for reinstatement and any other written instruments necessary or desirable under these rules. (Ord. of 1-4-00) Sec. 2-223. - Additional regulations. This chapter shall be cumulative to any other ordinance, resolution or act now existing. (Ord. of 1-4-00) Sec. 2-224. - Right to appeal. Any final decision by the city council pursuant to this code of ethics for city council members shall be reviewable by the superior court of Bryan County. The review by the superior court shall be limited to an inquiry of whether there was any evidence before the city council which supported the decision of the council. Provided however no action of the city council refusing or failing to take action pursuant to this code of ethics shall be reviewable by the superior court. (Ord. of 1-4-00) Sec. 2-225. - Conflict of interest. No elected official, appointed officer, or employee of the city or any agency or political entity to which this charter applies shall knowingly engage in any business or transaction or have a financial or other personal interest, direct or indirect, which is incompatible with the proper discharge of his official duties or which would tend to impair his independence of judgment or action in the performance of his official duties. (Ga. L. 1977, p. 3541, sec. 1.9) (Ord. of 1-4-00) Secs. 2-226—2-230. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - CONFLICT OF INTEREST, POLITICAL ACTIVITIES AND CODE OF ETHICS
Sec. 2-231. - Acceptance of gifts, gratuities, special privileges. (a) Employees shall not accept any gifts, loans, rewards, favors, or services that may reasonably tend to improperly influence them in the discharge of their official duties. This limitation is not intended to prohibit the acceptance of articles of negligible value which are distributed generally nor to prohibit employees from accepting loans from regular lending institutions. It is particularly important that employees guard against relationships which might be construed as or give the appearance of favoritism, coercion, unfair advantage or collusion. (b) Employees shall not use or attempt to use their position to secure an economic benefit or advantages, special privileges or exemptions for themselves or others including the use of knowledge obtained by through their employment or by virtue of their position. (c) Employees shall not accept employment or engage in any business or professional activity which they may reasonably expect would require or induce them to disclose confidential information acquired by them by reason of their official position. (d) Employees shall not accept payment from outside sources for professional services (i.e., teaching, instructing, speaking engagements, consulting, honorariums) when such activities are done on city time or when such services pertain to the purchase or sale of city property. (Ord. of 1-4-00) Sec. 2-232. - Proprietorship of creations. All plans, designs, reports, specifications, drawings, devices, inventions, and other items produced or created by employees during working hours or through the use of city facilities or equipment or at the request of the city shall be and become the sole property of the city. (Ord. of 1-4-00) Sec. 2-233. - Confidential information. Employees shall not disclose confidential information gained by reason of their official position, nor shall they otherwise use such information for their personal gain or benefit. (Ord. of 1-4-00) Sec. 2-234. - Conflict of interest. (a) If an employee of the city is an officer, director, agent or member of, or owns interest in any entity which is subject to the regulation of, or which has financial commitments with the city, they shall file a sworn statement to this effect with the city clerk. (b) Employees shall not transact any business in their official capacity with any business entity of which he or she is an officer, director, agent, member, or in which he or she owns a controlling interest, excluding civic, charitable or religious organizations. (c) Employees shall not have personal investment in any enterprise which will create a conflict or a perceived conflict between their private interest and the public interest. (Ord. of 1-4-00) Sec. 2-235. - Political activity. (a) No person employed by the city or retired from the city shall either publicly or otherwise hold himself out as a candidate in any city election while holding employment with the city, or receiving retirement pay or any compensation from the city. (b) City employees shall not take part in any political management or political campaigns in election of mayor or any member of the city council for the city during any period of time for which he is expected to perform work or receive compensation from the city. (c) No employee, official or other person shall solicit, orally or by letter, or be in any other manner concerned in obtaining any assessments, contributions, or services for any political party from any employee during his hours of duty, service, or work with the city. (d) Employees shall not represent the city by wearing any uniform or portion thereof that is issued by the city while he is participating in any campaign at any time. (e) The city in no way seeks to influence employees in their choice of party affiliations or candidates, recognizing that this is a matter for each person to decide. Therefore, nothing contained herein shall be construed to restrict the right of the employee to hold membership in and support a political party, to vote as he chooses, to express opinions on political subjects or candidates, to maintain political neutrality, to attend political parties after work hours, or to campaign actively during off duty hours in all areas of political activity. (f) Employees shall not utilize any city equipment or vehicles in support of any political campaign. (Ord. of 1-4-00) Sec. 2-236. - Outside employment—Limitations and approval requirement. (a) City employment shall be considered to be the primary employment of all full-time employees. No employee may engage in outside employment which will interfere with the interests of city service. Standards by which some employment is not acceptable include, but is not limited to: (1) Illegal activity; (2) Employment that by virtue of association will reflect upon the reputation of the city; (3) High hazard or fatiguing work which might detract from or reduce city performance. (b) Prior to beginning any regularly scheduled outside employment, employees will obtain specific written approval from their department head or his designee on request forms which indicate the name of the outside employer, the nature of the work, hours of work, address and telephone number where the employee can be reached. Such information will become a part of the employee's official personnel record. Employees are required to obtain approval from their department head or his designee for any change in a previously approved outside employment request. (c) Any employee accepting or engaging in outside employment under the terms of this rule shall make arrangements with the outside employer to be available to respond immediately to any emergency call of duty whenever the department head or his designee shall determine that the employee's services are necessary. (d) Employees sustaining injuries while engaged in outside employment are normally ineligible to receive benefits under the city's worker's compensation program. If an employee sustains an injury while engaged in outside employment, but is performing duties, within the scope of his city responsibilities (i.e. a police arrest), he may be eligible for partial city worker's compensation benefits. (e) Failure to comply with the provisions of this section will result in disciplinary action. (Ord. of 1-4-00) Secs. 2-237—2-250. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - RENTAL AND USE OF CITY FACILITIES; RULES AND REGULATIONS[7]
Footnotes: --- (7) --- Cross reference— Use of public property, § 2-205; special requirements for caterers, ch. 6, art. VI; drinking in public, § 50-8 et seq.
Sec. 2-251. - Limited application. This article and the rules promulgated hereunder apply only to those facilities which, from time to time, are designated by city council as being available for rent or use by the general public. (Ord. of 2-2-10) Sec. 2-252. - No unlimited availability. No facility of the city is available on an unlimited basis, and those properties designated by council as being available for rent or use by the general public are available only during the limited time or times specifically designated by council. (Ord. of 2-2-10) Sec. 2-253. - No long-term rentals. No facility of the city is available for use or rent by the general public for any period in excess of one day, unless specifically approved on a case by case basis by council. (Ord. of 2-2-10) Sec. 2-254. - Rules. The following rules and regulations shall apply to the rental and use of all available city facilities by the general public: (a) Rules for the use and rental of city facilities. The city provides and maintains its facilities and equipment for the primary purpose of governmental programs and services for its citizens and staff. In an effort to nurture community support and involvement, the city may allow the use of its buildings for appropriate educational, civic, cultural, and recreational activities. In an effort to be good stewards of such facilities, the city may limit use of facilities as described in this policy and/or may charge for use out of concerns regarding safety, security, wear and tear on buildings, increased utilities cost, inconvenience for staff members, liability concerns, and ethics concerns. It is the policy of the city that its facilities may be used by individuals or organizations for appropriate educational, civic, cultural, and recreational activities that do not interfere with city programs, activities, and events, on the following terms and conditions: (1) Organizations whose primary purpose is to provide funds, provide support, give other assistance for local activities or events shall have priority in use of city facilities. (2) Civic clubs or similar organizations whose purpose, among others, is to raise funds or otherwise provide support for programs of local interest shall also have priority. (3) A city facility may be rented or leased to individuals or organizations for a specific event when such use does not interfere with the normal operations of the city and when no city or other governmental activity is scheduled for said facility. City facilities shall not be rented to any individual or organization on a consistent, repetitious basis such as daily, weekly, or monthly. (4) City-sponsored activities shall have first priority. All other activities shall be scheduled on a "first come first serve" basis with the city manager maintaining a calendar of events which are scheduled in the respective facilities. The city may require payment of law enforcement personnel for safety and crowd control. (5) Use of city facilities for commercial or profit-making purposes is not permitted. However, city council may make appropriate exceptions on a case by case basis for such events as festivals or parades or other activities which directly or indirectly benefit the city, its citizens or the local area. (6) Any individual or organization using city facilities must reimburse the city for the use of facilities, for the cost of utilities, for staff needed for security, and/or cleaning purposes, and/or other incidental costs as determined by the city. Facilities cannot be used by individuals or organizations except during designated hours for each facility. The city manager shall make rules and procedures for each facility consistent with this policy which will implement the intent of this policy. (7) Before any individual or organization is permitted to use city facilities, representatives must demonstrate that the facilities will be protected and that those in charge can ensure to the city manager's satisfaction that the facilities will not be damaged in any respect and that any expense to the city will be reimbursed by those using the facility. (8) The city reserves the right to cancel the use agreement if it is found the facilities are needed for city or other governmental use or to rescind the agreement if it is determined that the intended use is inimical to the best interests of the city. Rental fees must be paid in advance and shall include all time required for the planned event - such as set-up, dress rehearsals, and clean-up. The individual or organization renting the facility shall be responsible for providing its own set-up and clean-up and after the event, respectively. Tables, chairs and other equipment shall be left in the same arrangement and condition as found. The facility shall be properly cleaned immediately after the conclusion of the event. If city personnel are employed by the individual or organization to provide the set-up and clean-up, they shall be paid directly by the individual or organization at a rate of at least one and one-half their regular rate as determined by the city salary schedule. The individual or organization renting the facility may be required to employ and pay security personnel as deemed necessary by the city. (b) Damage to facilities. The renting individuals or organizations shall reimburse the city for any damages that might occur to facilities during or as a result of their planned event. (c) Alcohol and tobacco usages. Except upon licensed premises or with a special permit from city council, no alcoholic beverages shall be allowed on any city property at any time and in any fashion. All city facilities are tobacco-free, and renting organizations and patrons must adhere to this policy. (d) Release of liability. The renting individual or organization agrees to release the city from all liability associated with the use of the building or facility. User evidence of liability insurance may be required. (e) Exemption of fees. When deemed appropriate, city council may choose to waive fees for sponsoring organizations of a governmental or civic-minded nature for events which serve to promote local or governmental interests. (Ord. of 2-2-10) Sec. 2-255. - All use and rental approvals handled by the city manager. All use and rental of city facilities by the general public shall be handled through the office of the city manager. (Ord. of 2-2-10) Sec. 2-256. - Reproduction of rules. The city manager is hereby authorized and required to reproduce and make available, through his office, to the general public copies of this article, the rules contained herein and any further rules promulgated by him/her under the authority granted by this article. (Ord. of 2-2-10) Sec. 2-257. - Initial decisions by city manager. All initial decisions regarding the rental or use of city facilities, not otherwise specifically provided for herein, shall be made by the city manager under the provisions of this article, and all such decisions by the city manager shall be appealable to city council. (Ord. of 2-2-10)

div.head: Chapter 6 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 22; public drunkenness, § 50-7; drinking in public, § 50-8. State Law reference— Georgia Alcoholic Beverage Code, O.C.G.A. § 3-1-1 et seq.; public drunkenness, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-41.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 6-1. - Sale to minors or incapacitated persons prohibited. No person who holds a license to sell alcoholic beverages shall sell or give away, or permit the sale or gift to, or the procuring for, any such alcoholic beverages to any minor, to any person who is mentally incompetent, or to any person who is physically or mentally incapacitated due to the consumption of liquor. (a) Government identification required. It shall be the duty of every licensee in the city to insure that every person acting on behalf of said licensee who is engaged in selling, bartering, trading, giving or otherwise furnishing any alcoholic beverage to any customer to require said customer to furnish and display an identification card issued by a governmental agency to verify his/her age. (Ord. No. 35, 5-21-74; Ord. of 12-1-08, §§ I, II) Sec. 6-2. - Persons under twenty-one years of age not permitted on certain premises. (a) No person under the age of 21 years shall be permitted to enter upon the premises of or remain on the premises of any business establishment operating under a class II on premises alcoholic beverage license, except that persons at least 18 years of age, who are bona fide employees of the establishment and who hold valid alcoholic beverage worker's cards, may be on such premises while they are on duty. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person under 21 years of age to possess any alcoholic beverage, except as provided in this chapter. (c) No licensee shall permit, allow or require any person in his employment or under his control who is under the age of 18 years to dispense, sell, serve or take orders for any alcoholic beverage, except that persons 16 years of age or older who are employed in business establishments which operate only under licenses issued for off premises consumption, except package shops, may sell or handle alcoholic beverages while on duty and during the course of their employment. (d) No package shop shall employee or permit any person under the age of 21 years to enter upon or remain in its premises. (e) It shall be unlawful for any person under 21 years of age to willfully misrepresent his/her age to any other person for the purpose of inducing such other person to dispense, sell, give or otherwise furnish to the person making such false representation, either directly or indirectly, any alcoholic beverage of any kind or description. (f) It shall be unlawful for any person under 21 years of age to consume any alcoholic beverage. (Ord. No. 35, 5-21-74; Ord. of 12-1-08, § III) Editor's note— Ord. of 12-1-08, § III, adopted Dec. 1, 2008, changed the title of § 6-2 from minors; offenses involving to persons under 21 years of age not permitted on certain premises. Sec. 6-3. - Minimum size containers. The holders of the license may purchase from wholesalers licensed by the state alcoholic beverages in sizes of one-fifth of a gallon or larger containers unless a particular brand is not packaged in these size containers, and then the license holders may purchase the brand in the nearest size to the minimum size container. (Ord. No. 35, 5-21-74) Sec. 6-4. - Reserved. Editor's note— Ord. of 12-1-08, § IV, adopted Dec. 1, 2008, repealed § 6-4, which pertained to package sales restricted and derived from Ord. No. 35, 5-21-74. Sec. 6-5. - Hours of sales restricted. No license holder shall sell, give away or otherwise dispense spirituous liquors, wines, champagnes or malt beverages between the hours of midnight Saturday and 7:00 a.m. Monday and between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 7:00 a.m. on other days. (Ord. No. 35, 5-21-74; Ord. of 6-19-84) Sec. 6-6. - Misrepresentation of beverages. It shall be illegal for licensees hereunder to add to the contents of a bottle or to refill empty bottles or in any other manner to misrepresent the quantity, quality or brand name of any alcoholic beverage. (Ord. No. 35, 5-21-74) Sec. 6-7. - Prices to be displayed. All licensees hereunder shall display in prominent places on the premises their current prices of all alcoholic beverages sold by said licensee by the drink. (Ord. No. 35, 5-21-74; Ord. of 12-1-08, § V) Sec. 6-8. - Reserved. Editor's note— At the request of the city, § 6-8, which pertained to election day sales and derived from Ord. No. 35, adopted May 21, 1974, has been repealed. The user's attention is directed to § 6-9. Sec. 6-9. - Sale of alcoholic beverages of any kind of certain days and/or during certain hours. (a) Definitions. (1) Alcoholic beverages means any liquid intended for human consumption which contains ethyl or drinking alcohol in any amount or concentration, and includes, but is not limited to, distilled spirits, wines, ciders and all malt beverages containing any amount of alcohol. (b) No license holder shall sell, give away or dispense any alcoholic beverage during the following days and hours: (1) On Thanksgiving Day for consumption on premises, from midnight of the Wednesday immediately preceding Thanksgiving until 9:00 a.m. on the following Friday. For consumption off premises, from midnight of the Wednesday immediately preceding Thanksgiving until 7:00 a.m. on the following Friday. (2) On Christmas Day for consumption on premises, from midnight of Christmas Eve until 9:00 a.m. on the day after Christmas. For consumption off premises, from midnight of Christmas Eve until 7:00 a.m. on the day after Christmas. (3) Monday through Saturday for consumption on the premises, from 2:00 a.m. until 9:00 a.m. each morning. For consumption off premises, from 2:00 a.m. until 7:00 a.m. each morning. (4) All Sunday sales of alcoholic beverages in the city are prohibited, except as follows: a. All establishments operating under licenses for consumption on premises may sell and dispense alcoholic beverages from midnight on the immediately preceding Saturday until 2:00 a.m. on Sunday morning. b. Any bona fide, full service restaurant holding both a license for consumption on premises and a special endorsement for Sunday sales may sell and dispense alcoholic beverages on Sunday from 12:30 p.m. until 12:00 midnight. c. Any holder of an alcoholic beverage caterers license and a special endorsement for Sunday sales may sell and dispense alcoholic beverages at catered functions on Sunday from 12:30 p.m. until 12:00 midnight. (c) Any business licensed to sell alcoholic beverages within the city will not only be prohibited from the sale of the same during the prohibited times set out above, but will also be prohibited of giving away or dispensing any type of alcoholic beverage in any manner during said times. (d) It shall be the duty of the owner or management of all licensed premises to maintain a copy of this section on such premises at all times and instruct each and every employee on the provisions thereof. (Ord. of 12-18-84, §§ 1—6; Ord. of 7-19-94; Ord. of 5-2-00; Ord. of 12-1-08, § VI; Ord. of 4-7-09, § II) Sec. 6-10. - Full legal compliance required. The holder of every alcoholic beverage license issued by the city shall at all times fully comply with all state and federal laws, agency and administrative codes and all of the provisions of this chapter. Violation of any law pertaining to alcoholic beverages shall be grounds for license revocation or suspension. (Ord. of 12-1-08, § XXIX) Sec. 6-11. - Sale from residence or home prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or dispense, for compensation, alcoholic beverages to any other person from any private home or residence. (Ord. of 12-1-08, § VII) Sec. 6-12. - Record of keg sales. Each retail licensee selling kegs containing malt beverages for consumption off premises shall register all such kegs in compliance with O.C.G.A. § 3-5-5 (c), and shall make available to the police department such registration documents. (Ord. of 12-1-08, § VIII) Secs. 6-13—6-20. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - LICENSES
Sec. 6-21. - License required; fee. (a) Each and every business, individual, corporation, partnership, association or other entity desiring to engage in the sale or dispensing of alcoholic beverages in the city shall be required to be licensed by the city and shall be required to pay all applicable license fees. (b) The city shall issue the following classifications of alcoholic beverages licenses: (1) Package shop licenses for the sale of whiskey, spirits and liquor by the package for consumption off premises only. (2) Sale of beer by the package for consumption off premises only. (3) Sale of wine by the package for consumption off premises only. (4) Alcoholic beverage caterers license for the sale of any alcoholic beverages for consumption at catered events only. (5) Sale of any alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises. These licenses shall be further sub-classified into three categories as follows: a. Class I—This class of consumption on premises license shall be held only by restaurants featuring a full service menu, and having a full kitchen and food preparation facilities. b. Class II—This class of consumption on premises license shall be held by taverns, nightclubs, bars and similar establishments whose primary business is the sale of alcohol for consumption on premises and who do not classify as "full service restaurants". c. Class III—This class of consumption on premises license shall be held by businesses other than full service restaurants where the sale of alcohol on the premises is coincidental to some other non-alcohol business, such as bowling alleys, billiard parlors, golf courses, and similar businesses. d. The holder of any class I license for consumption on premises, or any caterers license desiring the privilege to sell or otherwise dispense any alcoholic beverage on Sunday may apply to city council for a special endorsement on his/her/its class I or caterers license to permit the sale or dispensing of such alcoholic beverages on Sundays between the hours of 12:30 p.m. on Sundays and 12:00, midnight, if and only if such class I or caterers license holder meets all of the following requirements: 1. The licensee shall hold a current business license for a restaurant or catering business. 2. Such restaurant or catering business, within the last year, derived at least 50 percent of its total annual gross sales from the sale of prepared meals or food in all of the combined retail outlets of the individual establishment where food is served or catered from, or in the case of a new business, fully intends and expects to derive at least 50 percent of its total annual gross sales from the sale of prepared meals or food in all of the combined retail outlets of the individual establishment where food is to be served or to be catered from. 3. Such restaurant or catering business shall be a licensed bona fide, public restaurant or catering business which meets all health department standards and actually and regularly prepares and serves food on the premises or at catered locations from a full, on premises, operating kitchen. Additionally, in the case of a restaurant, such restaurant, in order to qualify for a Sunday sales endorsement must meet be equipped with a full kitchen facility that is staffed during all hours of said restaurants operation, and must include, at minimum, one cooking stove and one standard sized oven (this requirement is not met by a microwave oven and/or food rotisserie), one standard sized refrigerator and freezer and one kitchen sink. Said restaurant must further have adequate staff on duty at all times to both cook and serve meals to the general public, have a dedicated public dining room, offering substantial entrees and must have the full staff and ability to serve such entrees at any time said restaurant is open. Further, such restaurant or catering business shall provide a full service menu, and shall provide full food service to the public on any Sunday when alcoholic beverages are sold and dispensed. Provided further, that no restaurant may meet these food service requirements with any food that is catered or otherwise not fully prepared on the premises and served by said restaurant's own staff. 4. Any restaurant or catering business applying for such special endorsement shall at least annually, affirm its meeting these conditions by the filing of an affidavit with the city licensing department. Such affidavit may be filed at any time the above conditions are met by the establishment, but must be filed at least annually, with its license application, and city council may, in its discretion, require monthly filing from any restaurant or catering business applying for or holding such special endorsement. 5. Any establishment not fully complying with this section is hereby specifically prohibited from selling or dispensing any alcoholic beverage on Sunday. (c) The annual license fees for such licenses shall be as follows: (1) Package shop license, consumption off premises only, $1,500.00. (2) Sale of beer by the package, consumption off premises only, $500.00. (3) Sale of wine by the package, consumption off premises only, $500.00. (4) Any beverage, consumption on premises only, class I, $1,750.00. (5) Any beverage, consumption on premises only, class II, $1,750.00. (6) Any beverage, consumption on premises only, class III, $1,750.00. (7) Any beverage, consumption on premises only, caterers license, $1,750.00 (8) Special endorsement for Sunday sales, class I and caterers license, consumption on premises only, $250.00. (9) Special endorsement for sales on adjacent and contiguous premises, consumption on premises only, $250.00. (10) Caterers license for any beverage for one event only (this license is not renewable), $250.00. (d) All such licenses, except the single-event, caterers license specified at subsection (c)(10), which shall not be renewable, shall be issued and renewed on an annual basis only, and, in the event of an application for less than a calendar year period, the license fee shall be prorated down to the current month. (e) Should any license be revoked for cause, surrendered, or should any establishment holding a license for any other reason cease to do business, there shall be no proration or refund of any license fee paid. (f) Each license issued under this section shall be issued for a specific location only and may not be transferred to another location. A separate license and application is required for each licensed premises, except that a caterers license holder may cater alcoholic beverages to any lawful location in the city under that caterers license. (Ord. No. 3, 8-28-62; Ord. of 2-18-75; Ord. of 12-16-97, §§ 1—4; Ord. of 12-1-08, § IX; Ord. of 4-7-09, § III) Sec. 6-22. - Same; application. Those individuals, corporations, partnerships, associations, or other entities desiring to obtain a license or licenses as herein provided, must to apply to the mayor and council, in writing, for such an application, and submit the cost of the license along with the application for the same. (Ord. No. 3, 8-28-62) Sec. 6-23. - Same; duration. The term of the license herein provided shall be one year, beginning on January 1, of each and every year, and expiring on December 31 of the year in which issued. (Ord. No. 3, 8-28-62; Ord. of 12-1-08, § X) Sec. 6-24. - Standards for issuance. With respect to the issuance of licenses or the renewal of licenses, the mayor and council may, in its discretion, issue or deny any license or renewal of an existing licensed location based on the following standards, in addition to standards otherwise ordained herein: (1) Where there is evidence that, even though there is compliance with the minimum distances from schools, libraries and churches as provided in section 6-30, the type and number of schools, libraries or churches in the vicinity causes minors to frequent the immediate areas. (2) Where there is evidence that the location or type of structure could create difficulty in police supervision. (3) Where there is evidence that there are no licenses granted in the area or where there is evidence that the proposed area is adequately supplied with such licenses. (4) Where there is evidence that a license for the location would be detrimental to the property values in the area. (5) Where there is evidence that the license in that location would be detrimental to traffic conditions or that there is a lack of sufficient parking spaces for automobiles. (6) If the applicant was the previous holder of a license to sell alcoholic beverages, whether or not he has violated any law, regulation or ordinance relating to that business. (7) If the applicant was the previous holder of a license to sell alcoholic beverages, the manner in which he conducted the business, including but not limited to, the necessity for unusual police observation and inspection of the premises. (8) Where there is evidence of prior arrest or conviction of any of the employees at the location of the licensee. (9) Whether a person's license issued under the police powers of the city has been previously suspended or revoked. (Ord. No. 35, 5-21-74; Ord. of 12-20-05; Ord. of 12-1-08, § XI) Sec. 6-25. - Denial for criminal record. No license shall be issued or any renewal granted to any person, partnership or corporation where any individual having an interest either as owner, partner, principal stockholder, directly or indirectly beneficial or absolute, shall have been convicted or shall have taken a plea of nolo contendre within ten years immediately prior to the filing of the application for any felony or misdemeanor of any state or of the United States or any municipal ordinance, except traffic violations, or any violation of this chapter; the term "conviction" shall include an adjudication of guilt or a plea of guilty or nolo contendre or the forfeiture of a bond when charged with a crime. Likewise, no license or renewal shall be issued to any person, partnership or corporation where any individual having an interest either as owner, partner, principal stockholder, directly or indirectly beneficial or absolute, shall have pending against him/her outstanding indictments, accusations or criminal charges, or charges of violations of this chapter, for which no final disposition has occurred. Provided that where the violation or pending charge is for a misdemeanor, forfeiture of a bond or violation of a municipal ordinance, the mayor and council, may, after investigation, waive the same as a disqualification. (Ord. No. 35, 5-21-74; Ord. of 12-1-08, § XXVII) Sec. 6-26. - Citizenship of applicant. No license shall be granted to any applicant who is not a citizen of the United States. Where the applicant is a corporation, the principal stockholder must meet the requirements of this section and the license shall be issued to the corporation and the principal stockholder. If the applicant is a partnership, the requirements of this section shall apply to all the partners. (Ord. No. 35, 5-21-74) Sec. 6-27. - License fee. An annual license fee shall be charged for the initial license issued to any licensee as fixed from time to time by the mayor and council. All license fees shall be paid in advance on or before January 1 of each year. (Ord. No. 35, 5-21-74; Ord. of 12-1-08, § XII) Sec. 6-28. - Reserved. Editor's note— Ord. No. 12-1-08, § XIII, adopted Dec. 1, 2008, repealed § 6-28, which pertained to duration of license; proration of fee prohibited and derived from Ord. No. 35, 5-21-74. Sec. 6-29. - Time limit on application approved. All licenses must be obtained and fees paid no later than two weeks from the date of the approval of the application and if not so obtained, the permit shall be void. (Ord. No. 35, 5-21-74) Sec. 6-30. - Distance requirements. (a) No license shall be issued hereunder where the place of business of the licensee is located in any area prohibited by O.C.G.A. § 3-3-21, as amended, nor where the building of the proposed alcohol business is situated less than 200 yards from the nearest church, shrine, chapel or other place used exclusively for religious services or any school, college, state licensed kindergarten, where more than five children are kept on a regular basis, or state licensed daycare center, where more than five children are kept on a regular basis. (b) All distances set out hereunder shall be measured in the following manner: 1. From the exterior edge of the closed door of the main public entrance of the premises in which the beverage alcohol is to be sold or offered for sale, measure, in a straight line to the center of the nearest public street, road, or highway, including, but not limited to, the semi-public lanes of parking lots, driveways and other ways of vehicular ingress and egress available to patrons of the subject premises. This measurement establishes component "A" of the total distance. 2. From the point established in subpart (b)(1) above, measure by the nearest lawful means of vehicular travel to the center of the nearest public street, road or highway, including, but not limited to, the semi-public lanes of parking lots, driveways and other ways of vehicular ingress and egress available to patrons of the prohibiting premises. This measurement establishes component "B" of the total distance. 3. From the point established in subpart (b)(2) above, measure in a straight line to the exterior edge of the closed door of the main public entrance of the prohibiting premises. This measurement establishes component "C" of the total distance. 4. Where either the premises where the beverage alcohol is to be sold or offered for sale, or the prohibiting premises is located above the ground floor level of a multi-story building, measure vertically from the ground floor elevation of the main public entrance of the multi-story building to the finished floor elevation of either the premises in which the beverage alcohol is to be sold or offered for sale, or the prohibiting use. This measurement established component "D" of the total distance. 5. Add components "A", "B", "C" and "D" to determine the total distance for the purposes of this section. (c) No person, specifically including any alcoholic beverage caterer, shall sell, dispense or serve for compensation any alcoholic beverage within the prohibited area set out above. (d) Notwithstanding any other provision to the contrary, when and only when council shall, pursuant to section 50-8(b) of this Code of Ordinances, issue a special event permit for the same, a bona fide church may, within an enclosed building located entirely on its premises, dispense alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises only at such special event, held only by such bona fide church, and so permitted under section 50-8(b). (Ord. No. 35, 5-21-74; Ord. of 12-20-05; Ord. of 7-3-07(1); Ord. of 4-7-09, § IV; Ord. of 6-21-11) Sec. 6-31. - Suspension; revocation. (a) No license or special endorsement issued hereunder shall be suspended or revoked except for due cause as hereinafter defined and after a hearing before city council with at least a three-day written notice to the licensee of the time, place and purpose of the hearing, and a statement of said alleged due cause. Said licensee shall be entitled to appear before council at the hearing both personally and by attorney, shall be entitled to cross-examine witnesses against him/her/it, and shall be entitled to present witnesses in his/her/its own behalf. Due cause for the suspension or revocation of a license shall consist of any of the following: (1) Violation of any state or federal law, except traffic violations; (2) Violation of any city or local ordinance other than traffic violations; (3) Violation of any provision of this chapter; (4) Any material, false statement, or material omission relating to any license issued hereunder, including, but not limited to, any material, false statement or material omission on any application. (b) At all hearings for suspension or revocation of any license issued under this Code, council shall consider the following criteria: (1) The alleged violation(s); (2) The past history of the licensee; (3) The materiality of any false statement or omission that may be involved; (4) The harm or potential harm of the alleged violation; (5) The number and nature of calls to the police department relating to the licensee; (6) The harm or potential harm to the public; (7) The harm or potential harm to the licensee; (8) The number of past violations or warnings; (9) The number of past incidents occurring on the premises. (c) Following said hearing, and after consideration of the above criteria, council may take any of the following actions: (1) Suspend the license or special endorsement for any period of time, up to the remainder of the license or special endorsement; (2) Revoke the license or special endorsement; (3) Issue a warning; (4) Table the matter. (d) Any special endorsement shall be automatically suspended without the need for a hearing upon the licensee's failure to timely file any required affidavit. (Ord. No. 35, 5-21-74; Ord. of 12-1-08, § XIV) Sec. 6-32. - Renewals. All licensees shall be required to renew their licenses annually on forms prescribed by the mayor and council. (Ord. No. 35, 5-21-74) Sec. 6-33. - Reserved. Editor's note— Ord. No. 12-1-08, § XV, adopted Dec. 1, 2008, repealed § 6-33, which pertained to malt beverages included in license and derived from Ord. No. 35, 5-21-74. Sec. 6-34. - Transferability. (a) Licenses hereunder shall not be transferable, except as otherwise provided herein. In case of the death of any person holding a license, or any interest therein, the same may be transferred to the administrator, executor or the lawful heirs of the deceased person, if otherwise qualified. (b) Nothing in this section, however, shall prohibit one or more of the partners in a partnership holding a license to withdraw from the partnership in favor of one or more of the partners who were partners at the time of the issuance of the license. Such a withdrawal shall not, however, serve to bring any new ownership into the partnership. (c) Should a transfer of a location be approved, there shall be no pro-rata return of any license fee and the new location shall be considered as a new license. (d) However, a licensee may take in partners or additional stockholders where it is determined that the additional capital furnished is to be used exclusively for additional inventory or expanding the facilities of the business or for building new facilities and where it appears that the licensee himself receives directly none of the additional capital invested. Under this section an additional partner or new principal stockholder must be approved by the mayor and council. (Ord. No. 35, 5-21-74) Sec. 6-35. - Expiration for failure to begin operations. All applicants for licenses must within six months after the approval of the license open for business the establishment referred to in the license and begin the sale of the product or products authorized by the license. Failure to open the establishment and begin the sale within the six-months' period shall serve as automatic forfeiture and cancellation of the unused license, and no refund of license fees shall be made to the license holder. (Ord. No. 35, 5-21-74) Sec. 6-36. - Cancellation for cessation in operation. Any holder of a license who shall begin the operation of the business and sale of the product or products as authorized in the license, but who shall, for a period of three consecutive months thereafter, cease to operate the business and sale of the product or products authorized in the license, shall after the three months' period automatically forefeit his license, which license shall, by virtue of the failure to operate, be cancelled without the necessity of any further action. (Ord. No. 35, 5-21-74) Sec. 6-37. - Failure to furnish witnesses or information. The mayor and council shall prescribe forms for new or renewal applications. All applicants shall furnish all data, information and records requested of them by the governing authority, and failure to furnish the data, information and records within 30 days from the date of such request shall automatically serve to dismiss, with prejudice, the application. Applicants filing an application agree to produce for oral interrogation any person or persons requested by the mayor and council. Failure to produce the person or persons within 30 days after being requested to do so shall result in the automatic dismissal of the application. (Ord. No. 35, 5-21-74) Sec. 6-38. - False information. Any untrue or misleading information contained in or material omission left out of an original, renewal or transfer application for a license shall be cause for the denial thereof, and, if any license has been granted under these circumstances, same shall be cause for the revocation of the license. (Ord. No. 35, 5-21-74) Sec. 6-39. - Revocation for violations. Violation of any of the provisions of this article by the holder of a license hereunder shall subject the holder of the license to revocation of the license. (Ord. No. 35, 5-21-74) Sec. 6-40. - Investigative fee. Each initial application for license under this article shall be accompanied by a certified check or cash for the full amount of the license fee, together with a separate check or cash in the amount of $25.00 to defray the cost of investigation and report. If the application is denied and the license refused, the deposit representing the license fee shall be refunded, but the $25.00 payment shall be retained as cost of filing and processing the application. (Ord. No. 35, 5-21-74) Sec. 6-41. - Certification of familiarity with regulations. No person shall be approved for a license, or approved for employment by a licensee, unless that person shall have read these regulations in full text and certify in writing the fact of the reading and knowledge thereof. (Ord. No. 35, 5-21-74) Secs. 6-42—6-50. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - PREMISES SERVING ALCOHOL
Sec. 6-51. - Definitions. Alcoholic beverages. Any liquid intended for human consumption which contains ethyl or drinking alcohol in any amount or concentration, and includes, but is not limited to, distilled spirits, wines, ciders and all malt beverages containing any amount of alcohol. Licensee. As used in this article, a licensee is an establishment holding a license to engage in the sale of distilled spirits or spirituous liquors, wines, champagnes or malt beverages for consumption on the premises by the drink. Premises. The definite, closed or partitioned in location of the licensed premises, whether room, shop or building, where alcoholic beverages are sold by the drink, or in the case of a catered event, the location of the event, as set out in the permit for the event. In addition, the term "premises" may include, but only where specifically approved by council, and so endorsed on the license, any area that is directly adjacent and contiguous to the licensed premises, and which meets all of the following requirements of section 6-54 of this Code. (Ord. No. 35, 5-21-74; Ord. of 12-1-08, §§ XVI, XVII; Ord. of 4-7-09, § V) Sec. 6-52. - Sanitary maintenance of premises; conduct. All premises shall be kept clean and in proper sanitary condition and in full compliance with the provisions and regulations governing the conditions of premises used for the storage and sale of food for human consumption. It shall be unlawful to permit any disturbance of the peace or obscenity or any lewd, immoral or improper entertainment, conduct or practices. (Ord. No. 35, 5-21-74) Sec. 6-53. - Reserved. Editor's note— Ord. No. 12-1-08, § XVIII, adopted Dec. 1, 2008, repealed § 6-53, which pertained to employees serving drinks and derived from Ord. No. 35, 5-21-74. Sec. 6-54. - Sales off premises prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any sales to be made outside of the building, premises or place of business licensed for such sale. (a) If, and only if, approved by council and so endorsed on the license, the licensee of a consumption on premises license may serve alcoholic beverages outside the premises in any area that is directly adjacent and contiguous to the licensed premises and which meets all of the following requirements: (1) Full approval by council; (2) Has the same address as the licensed premises; (3) Is owned or leased and is exclusively controlled by the licensee; (4) Is not public domain nor only nominally under the exclusive control of the licensee; (5) The alcoholic beverages must be served from the same bar or serving location that services the main premises; (6) Any consumption on premises licensee applying for such special endorsement shall at least annually, affirm his/her/its meeting these conditions by the filing of an affidavit with the city licensing department. Such affidavit may be filed at any time the above conditions are met by the establishment, but must be filed at least annually, with its license application, and city council may, in its discretion, require monthly filing from any licensee applying for or holding such special endorsement; (7) No alcoholic beverages shall be sold, served or dispensed at any time in any parking lot, upon any sidewalk, or in any other public area adjacent to the licensed premises, and there shall be no "curb sales". (Ord. No. 35, 5-21-74; Ord. of 12-1-08, § XIX) Sec. 6-55. - Employees; criminal convictions. It shall be unlawful to employ in any premises used for the sale of alcoholic beverages by the drink hereunder any person in any capacity whatsoever, including performers, entertainers and musicians, who have been convicted in this or any other state or by the United States or any other country of soliciting for prostitution, pandering, letting premises for prostitution, keeping a disorderly place, illegally dealing in narcotics, sex offenses, or any charge relating to the manufacture or sale of alcoholic beverages. (Ord. No. 35, 5-21-74; Ord. of 12-1-08, § XX) Sec. 6-56. - Minors prohibited as employees. No licensee hereunder shall employ any minor in his establishment. (Ord. No. 35, 5-21-74) Sec. 6-57. - Reserved. Editor's note— Ord. of Apr. 7, 2009, § VI, repealed § 6-57, which pertained to advertising restrictions and derived from Ord. No. 35, 5-21-74; Ord. of 12-1-08, § XXII. Sec. 6-58. - Employees' familiarity with provisions. It shall be the duty of the management of premises licensed hereunder to maintain a copy of this article on the premises and to instruct each and every employee of the terms thereof. (Ord. No. 35, 5-21-74) Sec. 6-59. - Sales without license prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to sell alcoholic beverages for use or consumption on premises without the required license. (Ord. No. 35, 5-21-74; Ord. of 12-1-08, § XXIII) Sec. 6-60. - Customers bringing alcoholic beverages on premises. No licensee shall allow patrons to bring alcoholic beverages to his/hers/its establishment for the purpose of consumption on his/her/its licensed premises. (Ord. of 12-1-08, § XXIV) Secs. 6-61—6-69. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE WORKER'S CARDS
Sec. 6-70. - Alcoholic beverage worker's cards. (a) Employees. Every person selling, serving or dispensing any alcoholic beverage in every licensee's premises shall at all times have and maintain on their person a current, valid alcoholic beverage worker's card issued by the city police department. (b) Operation without. It shall be unlawful for the holder of any alcoholic beverage license to personally sell, serve or dispense any alcoholic beverage or allow any other person to sell, serve or dispense any alcoholic beverage in or about his/her/its place of business unless such person has a valid and current alcoholic beverage worker's card. (c) Persons requesting an alcoholic beverage worker's card shall make application for such on forms provided by the police department. Registration cards are valid for one year from the date of issuance. There is a ten dollar application fee for each card. Only one registration card is required per person, regardless of the number of places of employment. Registration cards are required for all classes of alcoholic beverage licenses. (d) Background checks, disqualifying offenses. No alcoholic beverage worker's card shall be issued to any person who has been convicted of any felony offense under the laws of this state or the United States, or of any violation described in section 6-55 of this chapter, or of any violation of this Code. Background checks will be conducted on all applicants, both for new cards and renewals. Provided further that any person who on the effective date of this chapterwas bona fide employed in a position requiring an alcoholic beverage worker's card shall not be denied either the initial issuance or renewal of any alcoholic beverage worker's card for any disqualifying offense the arrest date of which occurred prior to the effective date of this chapter. (e) Card to be carried on person. The holder of an alcoholic beverage worker's card shall keep the same on their person at all times while working in any licensed premises, and shall display the same upon the request of any law enforcement officer. Expired or suspended cards will be collected by any law enforcement officer. (f) Criminal acts. Any card holder who is adjudicated guilty of, or pleads guilty or nolo contendre to, or forfeits any bond for any act described in subsection (d) hereof, shall be subject to revocation or suspension of their alcoholic beverage worker's card as provided in section 6-71 of this Code. (g) Parental consent. No alcoholic beverage worker's card shall be issued to or renewed for any person under the age of 18 years unless such person tenders to the police department a bona fide and valid consent of a parent or legal guardian duly executed and upon forms furnished by the police department. (Ord. of 12-1-08, § XXV) Sec. 6-71. - Suspension; revocation. (a) No alcoholic beverage worker's card issued hereunder shall be suspended or revoked except for due cause as hereinafter defined and after a hearing in city municipal court with at least a three-day written notice to the holder of the time, place and purpose of the hearing, and a statement of said alleged due cause. Said holder shall be entitled to appear before the court at the hearing both personally and by attorney, shall be entitled to cross-examine witnesses against him/her, and shall be entitled to present witnesses in his/her own behalf. Due cause for the suspension or revocation of an alcoholic beverage worker's card shall consist of any of the following: (1) Violation of any state or federal law, except traffic violations up to its expiration date; (2) Violation of any city or local ordinance other than traffic violations; (3) Violation of any provision of this chapter; (4) Any material, false statement, or material omission relating to any alcoholic beverage worker's card issued hereunder, including, but not limited to, any material, false statement or material omission on any application.
